Hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzenes (CNB) emerges as a prominent topic of interest in catalysis research owing to its enormous industrial importance. However, hydrogenation of CNB is difficult due to the undesired side reaction of hydrodechlorination. As a result, selective nitro group hydrogenation in the presence of other reducing groups (C-Cl) continues to be challenging. Recent research has focused on the development of more selective catalysts. A huge variety of metal-based nanocatalysts and significant research outcomes have been reported in recent years. However, nanoparticle agglomeration and the cost-effectiveness of the catalyst are considered the critical controlling parameter for hydrogenation reactions. Carbon materials have become particularly promising carriers for such hydrogenation processes to overcome this challenge due to their unique chemical and structural properties. More recently, the widespread usage of novel carbons such as carbon nanotubes and graphene, as well as the fine-tuning of surface chemistry with heteroatom doping, have recently opened up new avenues for their applications in catalysis, particularly in CNB hydrogenation. Hence, this review aims at the selective hydrogenation of CNB on carbon-supported metal-based catalysts and summarizes the latest improvements in the use of different carbonaceous materials in this regard, and investigates the role of carbon support through the mechanistic pathway. The importance of hydrogenation reactions shows a substantial view in nitroarenes, quinoline, acetophenone, phenylacetylene, and cinnamaldehyde for the useful impact in pharmaceuticals, dyes, drugs, herbicides, pesticides, and fine chemicals production [1,3–6]. In this respect, selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzenes (CNB) for the preparation of chloroanilines (CAN) displays a wide applicable view in the corresponding industries [3,7]. In a mechanistic way, the electron-deficient aromatic rings coordinate weekly with metals, where the nitro group forms major coordination and hydrogenates first [8]. For this purpose, a lot of traditional technologies have been followed primarily to obtain the target product. Among them, the use of Fe/HCl, sulfide reduction, NaBH4, and hydrazine hydrate methods are mostly used [8–12]. However, challenges arise in these traditional methods due to drawbacks of the multistep process, generation of toxic waste, byproducts, and low yield [5,13]. In these challenges, a major drawback intensifies the dehalogenation reaction to generate acid and is responsible for reactor corrosion [14]. These scenarios in the large-scale industrial process faces a questionable spot regarding the selectivity of the reaction, cost problem, and societal impact. In this regard, solutions have been found with the noble metals (Pt, Ru, Pd, Au), and non-noble metals catalysts (Ni, Co-Mo-S) through liquid-phase hydrogenation [15]. But, the high cost of noble metals, high metal loading, nanoparticle aggregation, harsh reaction conditions, and short catalytic cycle forms a narrower range for applied purposes. Now, the enhancement of catalytic selectivity can be tuned through the reactants structure engineering manipulation for interaction energy, and configurations in active sites [14,16]. The process may follow the use of organic dehalogenation inhibitors [14,17] (like morpholines, tricresyl phosphite) or through the structural engineering by the involvement of inorganic components (doping of main group elements into a metal lattice) [14,18–20]. In the catalytic process, a larger active surface area with proper loading is necessary for high surface energy with minimum loading. In this regard, the selectivity of heterogeneous support is essential for catalytic effectiveness through strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [21–25]. The characteristic features for this purpose are linked to the high specific surface area, tenable porosity, narrow mesoporous size distribution, and chemical stability in harsh reaction conditions. The electron transfer from the support to metal particles enhances significant change in the intrinsic properties through electronic and geometric effects of catalysts which are mirrored in the catalytic performance [3,26,27]. So, vigilant choice of support is vital for the selectivity of the organic conversion. In the CNB to CAN production, carbon support shows higher transformation activity than the silica or alumina supports [8]. The significant impact of the carbonaceous supports in the heterogeneous catalytic systems comes from their chemical inertness, avoid condensation reaction, variable porosity, facility of electron mobility, high thermal stability, mechanical strength, low corrosion, and easy recovery of supported metal [8,28–30]. The chemical activity of the carbonaceous support follows reactant adsorption through the presence of “unclosed” graphitic layers, reactive open edges, and “dangling bonds” [29,31]. In this regard, the role of the surface oxygen functional group (-CO, -COOH, -COO, -OH) is very important in terms of their power in physical characteristic changes like polarity, hydrophobicity, acidity, and electronic state [32,33]. The doping of heteroatom (N, P, S) at the active surface varies the surface structure through the electron variation [32,34,35]. These types of surface functional group and heteroatom on carbon support engineering the position of metal catalyst for the favorable reactive pathway. The involvement of heteroatom (N, S, P), especially N to the place of carbon of support takes an important role in the catalytic activity and stability of hydrogenation reaction. In this sense, potential advantages have been found for nanoparticle catalyst distribution, nanoparticle-support interaction, and their resultant electronic structure [36]. From the above discussion on the use of carbon support in the hydrogenation of nitroaromatics, the current review article aims to cover the experimental point of view about the role of carbon support in different forms. The importance of the articles comes from the selective hydrogenation reaction of CNB in presence of carbon support. The influence of support on catalytic material through metal-support interaction, dispersion, dependance on geometric shape, and the influence of heteroatom on carbon support is discussed throughout the review article. This review is planned to report the selective hydrogenation of CNB in presence of activated carbon, graphene, CNT, CNF, and other carbon supports. The metal catalysts supported on these materials are also included in this review article. The relative kinetic and mechanistic pathway is also explained according to previously reported work. 2 Factors related to selective hydrogenation of CNB The Haber reaction mechanism was published in 1898 [33], is a widely accepted reaction mechanism for NB hydrogenation [37]. The hydrogenation reaction pathways in chloro-substituted NB are related with two acceptable paths i.e. direct and condensation, as shown in Fig. 1 [38,39]. In direct path, CAN is formed via chloronitrosobenzene (NSB) and chlorophenylhydroxylamine (PHA) intermediates, by the reductive transformation of the NO2 group in CNB. The product then undergoes further hydrodechlorination (HDC) and/or hydrodenitrogenation to produce aniline (AN) and/or chlorobenzene (CB) respectively. In the condensation path, the two very reactive intermediates of the direct path undergo condensation followed by reduction to generate dichloroazoxybenzene, dichloroazobenzene, and dichlorohydrazobenzene intermediate products [40–42]. The intermediate products, in the condensation path, is then transferred to chloroaniline through hydrogenation and homolysis way [42]. This transformation is generally favoured basic medium [5]. So, the identification of intermediate is necessary to consider the right possible mechanistic pathway [37,43]. The selectivity of CNB is a vital point in terms of cleaner environmental and economic profit. This alternative of the Bechmap process faces difficulties owing to the generation of a lot of intermediates and by-products. Unwanted C-Cl bond hydrogenation and azoxybenzene/azobenzene formation are two main important factors to regulate its selectivity [44]. So, high selectivity or activity is very important for catalytic efficiency that can be varied through catalyst morphology, structure, and electronic arrangement. To achieve these goals, researchers have been used techniques of alloy formation, catalyst particle dispersion, nanotechnology, support interaction, promoters, or inhibitors through different prospective [20,45]. The most frequently applied catalysts for the high-yield synthesis of CAN from CNB are nickel, pure platinum, or platinum-modified catalysts [38,39,46–48]. In terms of turnover frequency (TOF), the Pt-based catalysts show high efficiency in activity and selectivity through the minimization of dehalogenation [5,49]. The reported study shows that Pt/C show 99% conversion efficiency which becomes reduced to 13% in presence of oxide supports [5,50]. The high yield conversation is even more selective for ruthenium, rhodium, and iridium-based catalysts [48,51,52]. Platinum, rhodium, platinum and iridium catalysts are the most active for selective hydrogenation of CNB but limited due to economic reason [53]. However, despite their relatively high activity in the hydrogenation of haloaromatic nitro-compounds, catalysts based on iridium are rarely investigated due to the severe hydrogenolysis of carbon-halogen bonds during the hydrogenation process, resulting in a low selectivity to the corresponding amines [54]. Understanding the adsorption mode is necessary to find out the selectivity of CNB hydrogenation in any heterogeneously catalysed reaction. For a full analysis on the adsorption mechanism of nitro compounds, the reader is recommended to the specific review of Blaser et al. [55]. According to their suggestions, compared with other functional groups, after the strong adsorption of nitro groups on the metal surface, the surface will be covered by the adsorbed nitro groups, resulting in a decrease in chemoselectivity when introducing nitro groups. Despite the lack of experimental evidence, it is widely accepted that in order to be hydrogenated, the nitro group must be adsorbed parallel to the metal surface. Coq et al. [48] determined the positive influence of TiO2 as a support for the Pt-catalyzed hydrogenation of p-CNB shown in Fig. 2. Fig. 2 clearly demonstrated the preferential adsorption of NO bond on TiO2species migrating on Pt surfaces to enhance the SMSI. In support of the standard model, Corma et al. [56] used in situ FT-IR to show that, for an Au/TiO2 catalyst, NB adsorbs both on the metal and the support. In the theoretical investigation, it is expected that the reduction mechanism depends entirely on the adsorption method on the catalyst surface. Despite the expensive cost and restricted availability of Au, various efforts are being made to find an earth-abundant, highly active, and stable catalyst with great selectivity.The horizontal adsorption arrangement is structurally suited for hydrogenation of nitro groups in p-CNB on γ-Mo2N (111) surface [57] and boosts the transport of H+ from the surface to the NO portion. Other important factors that control product selectivity in CNB hydrogenation like metal particle size [58], bimetallic catalysts [59,60], solvent choice [61], stirring parameter, temperature, pressure, and initial concentrations of the precursors. The influence of the position of chlorine in the molecule of CNB is also important factor for selective hydrogenation. The review article also investigates the questions like what is the difference between ortho-, meta- and para-isomers when they are hydrogenated under the same conditions using the same catalyst? And in which case is it easier to achieve high selectivity for the corresponding chloroaniline? In this sense, the structural engineering for the suitable interaction energy between substrate and metal with the right configurations takes an important role in choosing an active site [14]. According to a previous report, an approach can be drawn through the selective poisoning/inhibitor like a catalyst with sulfur, nitrogen, and phosphorus atoms containing organics show interest [62] for the enhancement of CAN yield [14]. In another approach, design is processed on the basis of alloys and intermetallic formation with the doping of group elements B, C, N, S in metal structure [14,63,64]. Such types of approaches tune the metal electronic configuration through support interaction and elect the track of adsorption through reactive sites. 3 Challenges Hydrogenation process is widely used in the industry to produce functionalized anilines. But the problem of low selectivity causes significant amounts of waste acids and residues that causes serious environmental issues. The metal catalysts like Raney nickel, copper chromite, and noble metals also faces these difficulties during hydrogenation [65]. Therefore, a lot of challenges are standing with the CNB hydrogenation including. • The stability of the catalyst (noble metal, nickel, other metals) especially in the presence of HCl formation. • Selective regulation of reaction products under the premise of maintaining activity, including control of intermediates, azo, etc. • The difficulty of controlling the degree of hydrogenation in specific intermediate stages. • Use of earth abundant, non-toxic nature catalyst for both activity and selective nature [66]. • Trade-off is necessary between catalytic activity and selectivity in catalytic hydrogenation [67]. • In single atom catalysis, anchoring of single atom on supporting material show great challenge for effective catalytic site [68,69]. 4 Carbon supports 4.1 Activated Carbon (AC) as a catalyst support Activated carbon (denoted as AC) are widely used as support for the preparation of fixed bed catalysis owing to their large active surface area, low cost, well-defined pore distribution, and chemical stability in both acidic and basic medium [70–72]. AC from the biochar is generally show 2–2000 m2/g surface areas and the range depend on the used source and activation method [73,74]. These characteristic features make the support as valuable element for sustainable future [74]. Pd/AC is used commonly for the hydrogenation reaction in the industrial field. In this regard, surface functional group of the support material is very important for the active functionality and decide the particle size dispersion and chemical state of the metal atom [75]. AC support is used for the capture of Pt nanoparticles and the resulting catalytic activity is used for o-chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation. The decomposition pressure controls the size of the Pt nanoparticle and the larger size of Pt than support pore size leads to metal particle at the active surface area of support which reflected in catalytic efficiency [76]. In the hydrogenation reaction, deactivation of palladium nanocatalysts and their morphological changes reflected their uneconomic performance [36]. The platinum group metals are largely used for the chemoselective hydrogenation purposes but low selectivity towards nitro group leads to modification of process strategies [36]. In this regard, use of low cost and earth abundant transition materials with oxygen surface group containing activated carbon (ACOX) show high importance. The presence of such types of oxygen functional group creates interactions with nitro group that enhances the adsorption ability and hydrogenation selectivity [77,78]. Such type of oxygen containing functional groups also reduces metal particles agglomeration and offers better dispersion on supported material for better catalytic activity [3,79–81]. Ni supported on ACOX show chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes to the corresponding anilines. In the reaction conditions, 40 oC, 3 bar H2, 0.1 g Ni/ACOX catalyst, 0.5 mmol substrate, toluene as solvent produces 92.1% o-CAN from o-CNB in 240 min. The presence of oxygen surface groups is useful to stabilize the Ni particles and adsorption of nitro groups for efficient results [77]. In the TiO2 modified ACOX with Ni-based catalysts offers anchoring and nucleation sites for Ni atom through electrostatic and chemical interaction by oxygen containing functional groups. The enhancement of surface acidity owing to the presence of oxygen groups is feasible for inhibit hydrodechlorination of m-CAN and enhance the catalytic selectivity. The SMSI interaction between TiO2 and Ni prevents Ni-particles sintering and favours for higher H2 uptake for better catalytic hydrogenation. In this study, the high selectivity comes from the presence of electron enriched Ni δ- leads to an electrostatic repulsion between Ni δ- and C-Cl bond, which unfavoured the dechlorination process. The acid-base interaction between -OH at support and -NH2 in m-CAN is also prefer for dechlorination [3]. The effect of Ni-based TiO2 modified oxygen functionalised AC support for nitroarenes hydrogenation is show schematically in Fig. 3(a). The involvement of oxidizing agents (O3, H2O2, HNO3) during activation or purification of carbon tuned its functionalization through MSI [82]. Cunninghamia lanceolata carbon supported FeO(OH) nanoparticles show excellent activity (93 %−95 % for CNB conversion) for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes with good recyclability. In the hydrogenation reaction hydrazine hydrate is used, which is decomposed to intermediates (N2H3¯, NH2¯, H+, NH¯) on the surface of carbon support and stabilized. The stabilization of intermediate state shows high efficiency in the catalytic hydrogenation process and take prominent role for the conversion of nitroarenes to the corresponding amines [83]. The use of cobalt single atom on N-doped activated carbon support (Co SAs/NC) contributes high activity and selectivity towards nitroarenes hydrogenation. The presence of cobalt single atom act as active site, where N-atom control surface basicity and catalyst polarity. As a result, the dissociation energy of hydrogen atom is decreased and prefers -NO2 adsorption on the active surface for efficient hydrogenation reaction. The presence Co SAs/NC show 5.4 and 32.0 times higher activity than Co nanoparticles/NC and Co nanoparticles/AC respectively [84]. Sulphur-doped in the AC support is used for Pd nanoparticle dispersion and regulation in the hydrogenation of o-CNB. The presence of sulphur (1.42 wt%) in AC enhance the selectivity of o-CAN from 61.6% to 88% compared to Pd/AC. The selectivity becomes 99.9 % in presence of 1.65 wt% sulphur atom. The electron transfer from Pd to S show much importance in the catalytic activity than the geometric effect. The high activity and low selectivity of Pd0 becomes Pd2+ or Pd4+ in presence of S content (electron withdrawing effect of S) that make the catalyst low activity and excellent selectivity which reflected in the organic transformation [85]. The mechanistic pathway for hydrogenation in sulphur doped carbon support is schematically given in Fig. 3(b). Diaminocyclohexane functionalised AC complexed with Pd2+ is used to prepare supported Pd, Pd–B and Pd–Ni–B nanoalloy catalysts. Pd or its alloy particles were highly dispersed on the functionalized AC and have a narrow size distribution of 2–5 nm. In the catalytic performances for hydrogenation of the p-CNB, Pd-Ni-B catalyst exhibits high p-CNB conversion (98.6%) and selectivity (94.6%) with high TOF value 8316 h-1 compared to Pd, Pd-B catalyst due to high surface area and high dispersion of the functionalized AC supported nanoparticles. The incorporation of Ni strengthened the interaction of hydrogen with the active metal sites to enhance the catalytic activity [70]. Iron-modified activated carbon-loaded Pt nanocatalysts show extremely high activity, selectivity, and stability in the selective hydrogenation of o-CNB to o-CAN [86]. The electron-deficient state of the Pt nanoparticles, as well as their good dispersion on the surface of the active carbon, results in a substantial selectivity towards hydrogenation. The enhancement of iron concentration in the catalytic material provides high TOF value. The Fe-modified active carbon may cause the mesopores of the AC to fill up, making it harder for Pt nanoparticles to penetrate the pore channels of the AC. Bimetallic Ni-M/AC (M=Cu, Co, Fe or Zn) catalysts by incipient wetness impregnation methods are used for CNB hydrogenation [71]. The use of Cu, Co, Fe or Zn is acted as promoter and inhibits sintering of the nickel that leads to high amounts of Ni0 on the support surface. The synergic effect between promoter metals and nickel leads to reduction of NiO. Among all the catalysts studied, the Ni- Zn/AC-350 (350 indicates reduction temperature) shows the best catalytic performance with 100% conversion under very mild conditions. 4.2 Carbon black as a catalyst support The enormous absorption capacity, transportation, and bioavailability documented carbon black as one of the important carbon supports in organic transportation [87,88]. This carbonaceous nanostructured material is mainly a combination of amorphous and quasi-graphitic nanoparticles within the size range of 3.0–100.0 nm [89]. In the environment, the source of the carbon black arises from the incomplete combustion of biomass and fuels through both natural and human activities [88,90–92]. The microporous structure, high catalytic active surface area, high absorption capability, exceptional chemical stability, high conductivity, and low-cost synthesis procedure make these support suitable for use in large-scale applications [88,89]. The nature of initial hydrocarbons and pyrolysis factors decide different types of carbon blacks like channel, gas, thermal, acetylene, lamp, and furnace types [93]. Nanoglobular carbon [93], Vulcan carbon [94,95] are the types of carbon black that are used previously for the successful application in the hydrogenation of organic compounds. The variety of carbon black depends on its average size, degree of aggregation, specific surface area, and the production process [96]. In selective catalytic hydrogenation, Pd/carbon black shows a huge interest in multifunctional organic compounds owing to their controllable flexible structural and physicochemical characteristics [93]. Several reports by Mironenko et al. on the basis of carbon black supports for the hydrogenation of organic compounds showed its advantages and mechanistic pathway in the application field [93,96,97]. Zhang et al. [98] used carbon black and oxygen-functionalized carbon black for the modulation of the Pd nanoparticle’s electronic properties. The catalyst size variation follows a volcano-like trend and follows a longer reaction time for larger Pd particles. In the chemoselective hydrogenation of p-CNB, the oxygen functionalized group enhanced the activity of the carbon black which reflected in a shorter hydrogenation time. The surface modification of the carbon supports leads to the modification of the Pd nanoparticle electronic structure through charge transfer and varied substrate adsorption that influences the reaction’s chemoselectivity [98–100]. The presence of oxygen group functionality on the carbon black characterized the higher oxidation of the Pd nanoparticle attributed to higher adsorption of the substrates. In another study, carbon black (Vulcan XC-72R) is used with Ru-Pt bimetallic nanocatalysts for the selective hydrogenation of o-CNB in the absence of solvent [101]. The synergistic effect between Ru and Pt with a 1:1 proportion causes 1.5 times higher catalytic activity than the monometallic catalyst. The increase of catalyst amount in the hydrogenation reaction favors high catalytic efficiency but low selectivity owing to the higher exposed surface with dichlorination reaction. 4.3 Graphene as a catalyst support In supported catalyst chemistry, graphene possesses advantages for its 2D structure that supply a perfectly flexible platform in highly accessible functional groups or anchored metal nanoparticles can be grafted [102,103]. The sp2 hybridised carbon-based high surface hexagonal material used its monolayer framework and offers the facilities like intrinsic carrier mobility, capable mechanical strength, promising chemical, and thermal stability through its interconnected seamless porous structure [104]. The functionality of the graphene-based materials is varied by the introduction of different functional groups like -OH, -COOH and useful in a wide range of applicable fields [105]. The new functionality of graphene is also introduced by the involvement of structural defect by the doping of nitrogen or sulphur for modify the anchor metal interaction in catalysis application [106,107]. In the metal graphene interaction, there are generally three highly symmetric sites are responsible like top position of a carbon atom, mid-point of a C-C bond, and center of the hexagonal ring [108]. Graphene oxide-supported CuO nanocomposites is applied for the hydrogenation 4-nitrobenzene with aqueous NaBH4 reductant [111]. Nanocatalysts supported on the graphene may potentially promote the reductants’ electrons donation in the reaction media that enhanced the reduction efficiency. The synergetic coupling effect of CuO NPs and GO leads to the higher conversion of p-CNB with 92% selectivity. Fabrication of transition metal (Ni, Co, Fe) nanoparticles with graphene is used for the selective hydrogenation of 4-chloro nitrobenzene. Ni@graphene materials show high catalytic activity and selectivity at 575 oC pyrolysis temperature and able to convert 100% CNB with > 99% selectivity under mild reaction condition (1 MPa, 60 oC). The core-shell structure of Ni@graphene protect Ni-nanoparticle from leaching during acid treatment process and the catalytic process takes place at the graphene shell [109]. The core of Ni nanoparticles enhances the graphene shell activity and proceed for dihydrogen dissociation followed by “condensation way” mechanism as given in Fig. 4(a). Stable sub-2 nm Ir nanocluster (Ir-NC) catalyst on a mesoporous N doped carbon (MNC) support shows high-performance in the chemoselective hydrogenation. The enhancement of the reduction temperature leads to prominence in the regularity of graphene structure. The electron donation from the graphitic N to the adjacent carbon or Ir metal offers lower binding energy. As a result, the high activity is reflected in the hydrogenation reaction of o-CNB and gives 100% conversion, > 99% selectivity within 1 h duration time [1]. Reduced graphene oxide (RGO) supported-ruthenium catalyst shows high conversion efficiency (100%) for p-CNB to p-CAN with selective hydrogenation (>99.6%) [112]. The electron transfer between Ru nanoparticles and oxygen of RGO sheets occurs which is reflected in the catalytic activity. The smaller nanoparticle size range of Ru and its well dispersion over GO surface offers high adsorption ability for the reactants with shortens the residence time. RGO supported Ru catalyst (Ru/RGO) shows high selectivity (96 %) towards p-CNB to p-CAN conversion with a TOF 420 h-1 at relatively low temperature and hydrogen pressure (60 oC and 3.0 MPa H2) [113]. The combined effect of high dispersion of Ru (reduction of Ru3+ by aqueous NaBH4) on the surface of RGO and narrow particle size of Ru (1.5 nm) offered more active sites for the hydrogenation. As a result, the adsorption probability of reactant molecules is increased and speed up the reaction. The high activity of polystyrene brush-like polymeric film grafted on Pd nanocatalysts anchored RGO, is reflected in the 99.5% conversion efficiency, which is much higher than Pd/o-CNTs (75.5 %) (o-CNT indicates oxygen-containing CNT) owing to aggregation factor and curvature effect in the latter case [114]. The higher binding energy in Pd/RGO (0.2 eV) also support the above result that indicated the higher number of electron transfer from Pd to the support. Grafting of polyelectrolyte sodium polystyrenesulfonate on Pd/RGO modified the adsorption and the reaction pathway. The improved selectivity is observed for sodium polystyrenesulfonate modified Pd/RGO (82.9 %) over Pd/RGO due to the cover of the low-coordinated surface of Pd through grafting. DFT analysis confirm that the low-temperature synthesis favoured graphene with larger lateral dimensions and oxygenated surface groups (OSG) closer towards the catalyst surface via H-bond formation which accelerates the selectivity. The higher hydrothermal temperature generates more fragments and reduce the lateral graphene dimension [110]. The higher selectivity of p-CNB is due to the higher adsorption at polar catalyst surfaces through surface acid sites. Temperature-induced phenomena are shown in Fig. 4(b). DFT calculations on nonpolar graphene surface indicate the parallel position of benzene ring with graphene surface leads to π-π stacking interaction and adsorption. The introduction of -OH groups in graphene enhance the adsorption energy of the p-CNB increases owing to the formation of hydrogen bond between OH and O atom. Such type of interaction favours parallel adsorption phenomena and shorten the distance (Fig. 4(c)). 4.4 Carbon-nanotube as a support The catalytic decomposition of certain hydrocarbons leads to the production of carbon nanotubes (CNT) [115,116]. The structural feature of CNT lies in rolled graphite sheets and gives cylindrical shapes (length in micrometres, diameter ∼100 nm) [116]. The report by Iijima about the CNT applications [117] leads to a massive advance in this field [30]. The high surface area, high conductivity, corrosion resistance, and the presence of same sp2 carbon structure favours the intrinsic catalytic activity of the material as supports [118]. The presence of strong σ bond and π-bonds in the layered structures are responsible for its higher mechanical strength and electronic charge transport properties respectively [119]. The presence of high graphitic edge density of CNT than other carbon phase (like carbon black) makes it unique in functionality [118,120]. In the catalytic process, the interaction between metals and CNT is crucial for the growth of hydrogenation processes. A theoretical DFT calculation by Duca and coworkers [121] analysed to find the geometrical and electronic change during MSI for the designing of a suitable catalyst. The curvature nature of the nanotube leads to greater contact with Pd9 clusters than standard flat graphite sheet bilayers. The greater contact provides more interaction between catalyst and support through local ‘surface atoms’ extraction. CNT generally use two types of interfaces for the bond formation with metal crystals like the end-contact and the side-contact as shown in Fig. 5(a). The end-contact directs the formation of the covalent bonds at the interface, where side-contact favours the week bond formation at the outer or inner surface interface with the metal [119]. The presence of unfilled d-orbitals in transition metal shows characteristics attention due to interaction with CNT through the pz-orbitals of surface carbon [119,122]. The side-contact and end-contact are featured of these types of interactions and make transition metals more fascinating than no unfilled d-orbitals containing noble metals [119]. In this regard, the MWNTs growth on Si nanowires [123], FeCo-MWNT interface, SWNT-Co interface [124] are mentioned in previous reports as the existence of a stable end-contact [119]. The interface interaction over charge delocalization impacts the construction of metallic character for van der Waals bonding, which diminishes gradually from left to right of the periodic table [125]. In side-contact, the bond formation occurs generally weak and usually van der Waals bonding takes place [126]. Serp and co-workers [128] successfully synthesized low-priced nanostructured carbon-nanotube-supported ruthenium nanoparticles first time through the ‘in-situ’ process for the selective hydrogenation of p-CNB. The result shows 100% conversion efficiency with high reusability performance than Ru/C. The synthesis of RuNPs on CNT support using RuCl30.3 H2O with PVP (poly-N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) stabilizing agent under MW irradiation in the presence of alcohol or of an alcohol/water mixture [129]. The catalytic enactments of Ru supported on HNO3 decontaminated CNT were enhanced both in terms of activity and selectivity (reaching 100% toward p -CAN) with TOF up to 370 h-1 without affecting the C-Cl bond. Surface oxidation by HNO3 improved the MSI through strong communication between ruthenium nanoparticles and the carboxyl group of the decontaminated CNT surface compared to the untreated CNT surface. Such interactions help the homogeneous distribution of ruthenium nanoparticles on the CNT surface and also prevent nanoparticle agglomerations, which is confirmed by TEM images. Safer precursors are used to avoid the harsh condition during hydrogenation. In this aspect, hydrazine monohydrate is a relatively safe and inexpensive source of hydrogen that emits solely N2 as a by-product [130,131]. Hydrazine-mediated selective hydrogenation of several nitroarenes was successfully done at room temperature by CNT supported ruthenium nanohybrid, produced by the layer-by-layer assemble method [132]. RuNPs are powerfully anchored with the cationic poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride (PDADMAC) network owing to the interaction with the ammonium groups. Pd on carbon (Pd/C) is the most extensively used catalyst for the reduction of unsaturated organic compounds [133]. Palladium nanoparticles over CNTs and graphene support converted p-CNB to p-CAN with 100% selectivity at room temperature condition [134]. The Pd/CNT catalyst show higher activity than Pd/graphene due to the presence of higher active surface area in the former. To avoid nanoparticle aggregation, the Pd nanoparticles were synthesized over CNT and graphite oxide using EG as a reducing agent through the conventional impregnation process [135]. The presence of oxygen groups on oxidized CNT support makes it more active and selective catalyst than normal CNT support. The interaction between the support hydroxyl group and reactant nitro group accelerates the activation of the NO bond. In this regard, the presence of an electron-rich acid group provides an adsorption site for the aromatic ring that enhances catalytic activity. Repulsion between support π-cloud with Cl-atom and the product adsorption at the oxygen-rich centre in oxidized CNT favour the higher selectivity. The high activity and selectivity of CNT compared to Al2O3, and SiO2 support is proved during the hydrogenation of the nitro group of o-CNB. The better activity of the PdNP/CNT catalyst is due to the smaller size of the Pd particles and the absence of large aggregation as seen in the case of PdNP/Al2O3 and PdNP/SiO2 hybrids [89]. Wolfgang Maser et al. [127] are investigated pristine multi-walled CNT (MWCNT) supported gold nanoparticle by a facile linker-free deposition route. In complete conversions CAN are isolated in very good yields (94–98%). The high chemoselectivity of the AuNP-MWCNT catalyst can be explained by the substrate-support interaction as shown in Fig. 5(b). The hydrogenation of the nitroarene is explained by a strong π-π interaction between nitroarenes and the MWCNT, as well as an extra interaction between the cationic gold atoms present in the AuNP and negatively charged oxygen atoms of the nitro group of the substrate. Ir/MWCNT exhibited high efficiency and selectivity in the conversion of p-chloronitrobenzene to corresponding aniline due to the complete suppression of the hydrolysis side reaction of hydrodechlorination of carbon-chlorine bond in the substrate [54]. In polar protic medium, both catalytic activity and selectivity of chloronitrobenzenes are much higher than in non-protic solvents. Furthermore, the catalyst Ir/MWCNT is quite stable, with no substantial deactivation after five recycling [54]. The catalytic activity Ir/CNT are boosted by a strong contact between the iridium nanoparticle and the negatively charged oxygen atom on the nitro group [136]. Interestingly the important finding of the study is the less reactivity of oxidized CNT support catalysts. In terms of surface chemistry, the presence of oxygen groups [137] causes higher dispersion of the nanoparticles through strong interaction [138], which improves the catalytic performance of surface oxidized CNT. The inside and outside deposition of Co-B amorphous alloys on CNT leads to higher selectivity and conversion in former case for CNB hydrogenation [139]. The lesser aggregation of particles with smaller size may be causes higher activity in in-side deposition. The inside and outside deposition of alloys in CNT for nitroarenes hydrogenation is schematically shown in Fig. 6(a). In another study, the presence of Ru at the outside of CNT show much electron rich characteristics than inside Ru after heat treatment. The reason of such behaviours comes from the transfer of π-electron from the concave interior surface to the convex exterior surface of CNT through the diminishing of oxygenated surface groups. As a result, the outside Ru catalysts of CNT is capable for the hydrogenation of CNB than inside particles (Fig. 6(b)) [140]. CNT-supported transition metals modified Pt-based bimetallic catalysts PtM/CNT (M= Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) exhibits improved catalytic activities and yields of p-CAN compared to monometallic Pt/CNT [19]. PtFe/CNT catalyst shows TOF 0.47 s−1, while PtMn/CNT catalyst exhibits the highest yield of p-CAN (98.5 mol%). The worst catalytic activity is observed by PtCu/CNT may be due to metal poisoned by chloride ion from dehalogenation side reaction. Han et al. [141] are looked into the effect of transition metals on the hydrogenation of m- and o-CNB over CNT-supported Pt catalysts with different substrate concentrations. Fe decorated Pt/CNT catalyst show highest activity with TOF 0.37 s-1 and 97% yield of CAN. The electrical or geometric effect influences the hydrogenation selectivity by activating the nitrogen-oxygen bond [142]. The introduction of Fe in Pt/CNT greatly enhances the catalytic property of Pt for hydrogenation. The enhanced activity is most likely owing to the π-π stacking interaction between CNT and carboxyl groups of phthalic acid monopotassium salt [142], which makes CNT more dispersible and accessible to the metal precursor's aqueous solution [143]. The textural features of Pt–in/CNT and Pt–out/CNT are comparable and the addition of Fe to CNT increases the number of pores with diameters ranging from 2 to 7 nm, and it becomes more uniform in Pt–Fe(1.0)–in/CNT. Both Fe and Pt interact chemically with each other inside CNT, resulting electron donation from Fe to Pt to generate electron-rich Pt more easily than outside CNT and substantially easier reduction of Pt4+ to Pt0 inside CNT. As a result, the CNT cavity expands, limiting the growth of particles, and showing very high m-CNB in-situ hydrogenation activity. Rare-earth element promoted PtM/CNT (M= La, Ce, Pr, Nd, and Sm) catalyst is also applied for the hydrogenation of p-CNB [144]. The electronic effect of the rare earth element raises the turnover frequency of Pt atoms by activating the nitrogen-oxygen link that increases the catalytic activity and yield of p-CAN. N-doping into CNT affords defect construction with reactive active sites that enable negative charge on the adjacent carbon atoms and local charge density. The involvement of nanoparticles into N-doped CNTs make it more stable and active owing to electronic and structural promotional effect [145–147]. The involvement of hollow N-doped CNT with in situ form Ni nanoparticles (Ni@N-CNT) leads to high activity in the conversion of CNB to CAN (>99%) in methanol solvent. The heterojunction formation between Ni nanoparticles and the support enhances the activity of the catalyst through the transformation of the electrons from the higher Fermi energy level of Ni to carbon support. The Mott-Schottky effect influences the electron distribution at the heterojunction that reflected in the selective hydrogenation as figured in Fig. 7(a) [145]. The presence of functional groups on the surface of CNT leads to well anchor features for metal catalyst and the presence N-containing groups is responsible for high dispersion [148,149]. The higher surface area of CNT supports is attractive for Ru nanocatalysts but fails to show activity in presence of Fe3O4 [148]. Pyrolysis of chitosan based CNT that doped with pyrrolic N (0.33 %) and graphitic N (0.30 %) exhibits high activity with selectivity during nitroarenes hydrogenation. The synergistic effect of pyrrolic nitrogen and graphitic nitrogen leads to higher catalytic activity and selectivity [150]. The use of ultrasmall-sized platinum nanoparticle in high amount nitrogen doped CNT support is capable to show two-fold high activity than Pt/oxygenated CNT. The presence of high amount of nitrogen shows anchoring effect with high dispersion that reflected in the catalytic activity, selectivity, stability, and tolerance values for different substituted nitroarenes. The electron rich chemical state of Pt nanoparticle leads to higher selectivity for halonitrobenzenes to haloanilines as given in Fig. 7(b). The MSI and electron donor capacity of nitrogen sites in supports able to stabilize the Pt nanoparticles [151]. 4.5 Carbon nanofibers as a support CNF with a variety of nanostructures, tuneable graphene sheet orientations, and diverse CNF edge structures recognized it as effective catalyst supports. In selective hydrogenation process, CNF support material shows high importance in terms of their cost-effective synthesis, pure phase, mechanical strong outstrip, chemically inertness, higher porosity, lower tortuosity, and absence of micropores that limit mass transfer possibility [152,153] purpose. CNF, combination of active carbon and graphite structure, is stable in harsh condition and able to evacuate heat generation during reaction [152]. The well-developed pore structure aids in reducing the sintering process which resulting in enhanced metal dispersion on support system [154]. Highly dispersed nickel catalysts supported on CNF demonstrated good catalytic activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of o/m-CNBs to o/m-CANs in comparison to Ni/AC. The catalyst converted 91% o-CNB with 98% selectivity within 30 min time interval. o-CNB conversion. The high catalytic activity of CNF than AC may be due to the SMSI through unique electronic effects and better mass transfer of CNF support [155]. The Ni-NiFe2O4/CNF composite shows high selective to the hydrogenation of aromatic nitro group and the productivity is controllable through the H2 pressure adjustment. The higher surface area of CNF offers large dispersion of nanoparticle that enrich the catalytic active site. The mechanistic process, the H2 is activated to H atom by Ni nanoparticles and transferred electron to the acceptor nitro group of nitroarenes through CNF support. The combination of H with nitro group leads to the hydrogenated expected product. The hydrogenation of nitro group delivers low hydrogen activated ability of the corresponding molecule and unable to react with C-Cl at low H2 pressure, resulting high selectivity [156]. Motoyama et al. used three types of CNF like platelet, tubular, and herringbone separately with Ir nanoparticle for the hydrogenation of CNB. These types of CNF depend on graphite layer orientation, e.g., for perpendicular, parallel, and stacked obliquely indicates platelet, tubular, and herringbone respectively. The p-CNB is successfully converted to corresponding p-CAN with a 99% yield under 11 h reaction time in presence of tubular CNF support. The high catalytic activity and higher recyclability effort of the tubular CNF support may be coming from generated electronic effect from the interaction between Ir nanoparticle and CNF support [157]. The use of three types of CNF is also done by Takasaki et al. for Pd and Pt nanoparticle dispersion. In a comparative study with Pt/C, Pt/tubular CNF show similar results with large number of byproducts than other supports. The other forms of CNF (platelet and herringbone) both with Pd and Pt show up to 96% selectivity for hydrogenation but differ in turnover frequency (Pt>Pd). In the hydrogenation process, the addition of n-octylamine offers high selectivity product without retarding the process. Here, the metal support electronic interaction shows high importance in the selective hydrogenation rather than the size effects of the nanoparticles [158]. 4.6 Carbon supported Promoters The promoter is a catalyst enhancer that has no catalytic characteristics of its own. The presence of promoter enhances accessible surface area, stabilize against crystal formation with sintering, and improved the mechanical strength of the catalysts. To date, it is anticipated that the role of promoters can increase metal dispersion affect [159] and enhanced the electronic surroundings of the metal sites [160]. Co-doped MoS2 nanosheets used for nitroarene reduction, where, the integration of cobalt ions in the MoS2 lattice is the fundamental cause for the promoted catalyst's efficiency [161]. The Co-doped MoS2 layers' show superior catalytic activity due to a combination of (a) metallic 1 T phase stabilization and (b) improved electron capture that supply to the nitroarene substrates via reversible redox reactions at the Co sites. The good catalytic activity and chemoselectivity achieved for the use of Ni promoters. Promoter–active component interactions, as well as promoter–active component–support interactions take critical role in promoted catalysts. According to the findings, the strong contact between Pt and Cu in the Pt-Cu bimetallic catalyst considerably increased the catalytic performance in terms of activity/selectivity and stability [162]. Mahata et al. [163] investigated the hydrogenation performance of o/p- CNB using Cu as promoter on CNTs and activated carbon-supported Pt nanoparticles. According to the authors, there is some sort of interaction between Pt and Cu that covers the majority of the Pt surface and adequately activates the N = O bond of CNB, that increases the catalyst selectivity and stability. Such interactions are basically due to the large interfacial contact area of Cu surface enrichment is confirmed by XPS measurements. The CNT-supported catalysts have better selectivity than activated carbon owing to their large mesoporous surface area and lack of microporosity, which decreases internal mass transfer limitations. Supported Rh-Cu could be a good hydrogenation catalyst for organic substrates [164]. H2 chemisorption results revealed low hydrogen chemisorption due to Cu covering most of the Rh surface, thereby controlling hydrogen chemisorption. As a result, the Cu on Rh's surface helps to activate the NO bond and enhances hydrogenate selectively to p-CAN. Fig. 8 depicts the surface reaction of p-CNB with hydrogen on an activated carbon-supported Rh-Cu catalyst. Fu et al. [165] explored Fe-promoted activated carbon-supported Pt catalysts for selective hydrogenation of p-CNB to p-CAN. The addition of an appropriate amount of Fe (4 wt%) to the catalyst increase activity and selectivity toward p-CAN significantly. The XPS analysis (Fig. 8c-d) indicates the electron transport from Pt particles to Fe2O3 slows the hydrochlorination reaction by turning Pt nanoparticles in the Fe/AC catalyst into an electron-deficient condition. The conversion of p-CNB reduces from 65% to 33% when Fe loading is increased from 4 wt% to 6 wt%, which could be due to partial coating of the Pt surface by excess FexOy. Nickel carbides promoter was found to have a positive effect on CNF [166]. Ni-decorated catalyst is used for selective hydrogenation of o- and p-CNB to the corresponding CAN. NiC triggered liquid phase hydrogenation with 98.5% conversion of o-CNB and 98.1% selectivity to o-CAN. A synergistic catalytic action between active metallic nickel and nickel carbide species take place for the resultant product. Electron transport between nickel carbide and adjacent CNF in NiC-Ni/CNFs nanocomposites leads to increased activity of the catalyst. The liquid phase hydrogenation of CNB is assessed through the use of Pt-Sn-B/CNT catalyst [167]. The catalyst shows higher catalytic performance compared to Pt–B/CNTs, Raney Ni, Pd/C, and Ni powder. In the presence of Sn, the metallic Pt becomes more electron enriched and B supplied partial electrons to the metal. Such type of electron donation makes the Pt as active sites which weakened and activated the N = O link by promoting hydrogenation. 4.7 Doped carbon material support The presence of nitrogen functionalities in activated carbons can help in the hydrogen dissociation step when metal nanoparticles are supported on them [168,169]. Co nanoparticles supported on nitrogen-free and nitrogen-doped activated carbon (NAC) have been prepared, and the influence of nitrogen groups and the reduction treatment in the catalytic reduction of p-CNB is studied [26]. The presence of nitrogen groups on the surface of the carrier increases the surface area of NAC, which prevent their migration and the consequent blockage of the narrowest pores. The interaction of cobalt particles with nitrogen functional groups (forming Co4N), and the creation of mesopores in the support during the activation process regulate the improved catalytic activity. To overcome mass transfer restrictions, porous core-shell polymer (m-phenylenediamine named as m PDF) N-doped carbon nanospheres decorated with Pd-Cu nanoalloys were effectively synthesized and employed as an important catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of p-CNB ( Fig. 9a) [170]. Owing to the interaction between alloy and N-doped carbon support leads to the superficial distribution of metal in the porous shell of support. The electron-rich Cu influence the adsorption orientation of the substrate as shown in Fig. 9(b). The repulsive interaction between electron-rich Cu and the negative part of p-CNB may minimize the chance of Cl being attacked, suppressing the breakage of the C-Cl bond for dehalogenation reaction. For Ni0 @C–N/SiO2 catalyst, the synergistic effect between Ni and N-doped carbon leads to high reaction rate and selectivity for p-CNB hydrogenation [171]. Pd nanoparticles are supported on sulfur-doped activated carbon (CS), show high selectivity for o-CAN. The 1.42 wt% S content in Pd/CS2 enhances the selectivity for o-CAN from 61.6% to 88% compared to Pd/AC [85]. A larger quantity of doped-S could lead to better selectivity. The electronic factor between the S and Pd atoms is a more dominant factor than the geometric shape of the active metal. More active Pd0 in Pd/AC is converted to less active Pd2+/ Pd4+ as the S concentration increased, contributing to the lower activity and high selectivity. A sulfur-doped porous carbon-supported Pd catalyst was successfully developed by high-temperature carbonization of a sulfur-rich organic polymer in an inert gas atmosphere [172]. Pd/CSx show superior selectivity than Pd/C, attributed to the mesoporous structure of Pd/CSx and the interaction of S with the metal Pd atom, resulting in an electron-deficient state and lowering of Pd hydrogen absorption capacity. Li et al. [173] synthesized Pd-P-C framework structure by calcining sodium hypophosphite and ethylene glycol in an inert gas atmosphere and loading Pd on a P-doped carbon layer impregnated on AC. The Pd-P catalyst demonstrated up to 99.9% selectivity for aromatic haloamines in the chemoselective hydrogenation of p-CNB, and strong catalytic stability is used in their work to investigate the role of phosphorus in the P-doped Pd catalyst supported on activated carbon. XPS studies indicated adding of electron-rich P to the carbon layer improves the electron-rich characteristic of the Pd atom and that electrons are likely transported from C to the Pd atom via the P atom, implying that phosphorus might be used as an electron storage medium. The previously reported carbon-based supports for the successful conversion of CNB to CAN are summarised in Table 1. 5 Kinetics and mechanistic approach Hydrogenation of CNB is a complicated process due to the production of many by-products [180]. There are many factors like the amount of nanocatalyst, concentration of nitroarenes, hydrogen gas pressure, catalyst particle size, dispersion on support materials directly influence the hydrogenation process. In a catalytic hydrogenation reaction, CNB first disperses on the catalyst surface through kinetic control of mass transfer. This may form transition state of CNB in presence of metal catalyst owing to the electrophilic character of the reactant functional group and metal oxidation state. The hydrogenation process is then triggered from the formed transition state through the electron transfer from the catalyst to the reactant [6]. If in a kinetic reaction, ‘A’ is the reactant, ‘B’ is the expected hydrogenated product under H2 pressure, then the ordinary differential equations can be written as follows (Eqs. 1–6) [181]. (1) d C A dt = − r (2) d C B dt = r (3) d P H 2 dt ≈ 0 (4) C A = C A 0 for t = 0 (5) C B = 0 for t = 0 (6) P H 2 = P total − P solvent 0 The above equations are considered under the conditions of closed, dissentious, perfectly mixed reactor, high excess of hydrogen, and presence of unreacted solvent. In the reaction kinetics the hydrogen pressure and temperature of the reaction medium take an important role for the completion of the reaction. The high pressure of hydrogen increases the solubility of hydrogen which enhances the accessibility of the catalyst surface for hydrogen molecule [182]. Coq et al. proposed a modified Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic model to explain the kinetics of hydrogenation of CNB over Pt surface [58]. In this regard, author assumed that (i) there is a competition between hydrogen and CNB for adsorption on Pt surface, and (ii) Under a saturated condition by CNB, the place is also available for chemisorption of H2 molecule according to the Fig. 10 (a). The rate of the hydrogenation for CNB at the surface reaction can be expressed as follows (12) r = k θ B θ H Here k is the rate constant of the surface reaction. In a comparative hydrogenation process of nitrobenzene, p-CNB, and o-CNB, Mahata et al. studied their kinetics pathway in NiC catalyst [183]. The concentration of the reactants at different time interval are fitted in zero (Eq. 13) and first order (Eq. 14) rate law as follows (13) C = C 0 − kt (14) ln C = ln C 0 − kt Where C0 and C are the reactant concentration at time t = 0, and t = t respectively. The NB, and p-CNB hydrogenation data fitted well linearly with zero order kinetic path whereas o-CNB follow first order kinetic path as given in Fig. 10 (b-c). The deviation of o-CNB in zero order kinetic path can be explained through the adsorption of the substrate on the active heterogeneous catalyst surface. In this regard, the position -Cl with respect to -NO2 group is very important in the surface adsorption mechanism. The nearest position of the functional groups in o-CNB make the surface adsorption weaker than the others which makes unsaturated surface and increase reaction velocity [183]. In a particle solution, the solid/liquid interface reaction kinetics was determined by the internal diffusion and the external diffusion processes. In hydrogenation reaction, temperature, H2 pressure, and stirring intensity influence the reaction kinetics. Li et al. [142] used 2 wt% Pd/C catalysts for CNB hydrogenation and the most favourable reaction conditions were T = 383 K, stirring speed = 900 rpm, and feeding ratio o-CNB/catalyst = 200/1 (m/m). The catalytic hydrogenation reaction followed zero-order concerning hydrogen and a first-order concerning o-CNB. The apparent activation energy of the process was 60.82 kJ/ mol. In an another study, Mahata et al. [184] carried experiments at 1600 rpm to avoid mass transfer limitations. The rate of hydrogenation of o-CNB to o-CAN, as well as the rate of side reactions, appears to increase as the reaction temperature rises. The addition of an appropriate amount of 4 wt% Fe in 0.3% Pt (0.3% Pt–4%t Fe/AC) leads to a significant increase in activity and selectivity for p-CNB hydrogenation, even at high temperature and H2 pressure [165]. The influence of temperature in the range 90–110 oC enhanced p-CNB conversion efficiency gradually from 56.2% at 90 oC to 100% at 110 oC, with a maximum yield of 99.6% p-CAN [112]. Careful selection of suitable solvents is critical for chemists to understand the reaction environment that controls chemical transformations. The solvent can modify the solubility of reactants and reagents, diffusion rate, and other kinetic and thermodynamic characteristics of the reaction by solvating the reactants and active surface centres of the catalyst. Clean solvent water is thought to be a safer solvent for full nitro group reduction because it lowers the activation energy of the catalytic process [185]. Cheng et al. [169] investigated the influence of water on the hydrogenation of o-CNB in ethanol, n-heptane, and compressed carbon dioxide over Pd/C and Pt/C catalysts. They discovered that the o-CNB hydrogenation rate decreased in ethanol, but surprisingly increased in n-heptane and compressed carbon dioxide with the addition of water. Here, the involvement of water activates the NO2 functional group via hydrogen bonding interactions, and also change the hydrogen solubility in ethanol and n-heptane. Doris et al. [132] observed the better catalytic properties in water medium for the conversion of p-CNB to p-CAN. Ni-nanoparticle dispersed on nitrogen-doped carbon quantum dots and the resultant material show zero-order reaction kinetics during p-CNB hydrogenation. The variation of temperature (343–373 K) during hydrogenation reaction followed straight line with 74.94 kJ mol-1 activation energy [186]. In the kinetic mechanistic pathway, the identification of the rate determining step is most important to recognise the motif of the reaction. The identification of intermediate state like the formation of nitrosobenzene, phenylhydroxylamine, azobenzene etc. are detected in solution through online spectroscopic techniques during hydrogenation process. The intermediate species make an equilibrium in solution and the reversibly adsorbed on the active catalyst surface for the hydrogenated product [187,188]. The formation number of intermediates varies according to the substrates structure, used catalysts, and other reaction parameters. Here, it should be mentioned that the dissociation of hydrogen molecule on metal surface is favourable both kinetically and thermodynamically. The hydrogenation pathway bank on the role of carbon-support possessions mainly metal-support interaction, confinement effects, spillover phenomena, and the presence surface functional groups [189]. These types of functionalities are also varied according to the size, morphology, and the number of nano catalysts in support materials. 5.1 Metal-support interaction The catalytic performance of metal particle may influence by the metal -support interaction through different ways like the variation of metal particles size, morphology, charge transfer, or the direct support activity towards the reaction [189,190]. But the research cannot find clearly the specific contribution in the catalytic activity to control the interaction mechanism till to date. The local strain and the presence of defects on the support (graphene) material influences the metal particle adsorption and migration. These types of effects influence the charge transfer between metal and support and varied the activity [191–193]. The metal-support interaction is related to the different phenomenon in the catalytic performance and the variation of catalyst properties is followed by support. According to the previous reports, the thickness of the carbon film effects on its strain [194], carbon supports create bond-length disorder for Pt through anisotropic distortion in the cluster [195], morphological changes of the catalyst nanoparticles occur after disruption [189], adsorption on support may changes the metal coordination number [196], and the effects are also found in the binding energy of metal catalysts [189]. 5.2 Confinement effects The confinement effect is generally found in the case of CNT support due to the presence of inner and outer surface positions. The effects are also find in the cases of porous carbon materials and 2D graphene substrates [197,198]. The presence of π-orbitals in the support and their contribution in the site selectivity for the interaction with metal decide the facet of reactivity. In a comparative study between graphene and CNT, the orientation of the π-orbitals is differed. In graphene, the π-orbitals are perpendicular in the corresponding graphene layer where in CNT the surface bending position creates convex and concave position. The curvature nature induces rehybridization in the materials and form a blend between sp2 and sp3 orbitals [189]. This type of different effects in the support surface make difference in the interaction with metal catalysts and reflected in the catalytic activity. The charge transfer between metal and CNT support able to enhance electron density at the convex surface and useful to produce surface oxy groups through adsorbed O2 molecule [199,200]. 5.3 Spillover phenomena ‘Spillover’ phenomena indicate the migration of H atoms from metallic particles to a support [189,201]. The rate of spillover can compete with the rate of the catalytic reaction. For the hydrogenation reaction, the molecular hydrogen is activated and dissociated in presence of support adjacent transition metal catalyst particles. The formation of H species is than migrate to the support materials surface through diffusion and recombination process. In this pathway, hydrogen migrates through the formation of different type species like hydrogen radicals, protons, hydrides, and activated hydrogen [201]. The presence of shuttle gas (like H2O, HF, NH3) [202,203] or the presence of oxygenated surface group expand spillover process easier through coadsorption or decrease of diffusion barrier respectively [202,203]. The direct evidence of the phenomenon can be analysed through inelastic neutron scattering, where the analysation finds the state of hydrogen, and the spatial distribution of adsorbed hydrogen [204]. 6 Role of carbon support Carbon-supported metal catalysts are used worldwide due to their easy availability, low-cost, excellent stability, trivial effect on reaction, and high-level degree of dispersion [67]. The nature of support decides the physical and chemical properties of the supported metal catalysts through their interaction phenomena [121]. The phenomenon allows the electrical transportation at the interfaces or/and influence the catalytic growth of supports [119]. A lot of supportive role have been performed by carbon support material that make the catalytic material more active towards corresponding reaction site and selectivity. (i) Dispersion effect. Carbon support use their large surface area for the dispersion of catalyst material and reduce the agglomeration of the materials [205]. The dispersion leads to expand the active sites of the catalytic materials for the adsorption of the nitroaromatics and proceed the kinetic reaction in a favourable way. The dispersion effect is enhanced with the number of oxygen functional group on the carbon support material [206–208]. Sometimes this effect is also hindered due to these functional groups according to the literature report [206,209]. In this regard, exposed metal surface and nanoparticle density show high impact than active surface area [148]. (ii) Modification of electronic character. The introduction of support influences the electronic character of the catalytic material through the support-material electronic interaction [206]. In this regard, the presence of oxygen groups (-COOH, -PhOH, -COOR) on the carbon support take an important role for the electronic interaction. These types of groups are liable for the different redox properties [206] and create different polarity in the supports [148]. The strong interaction between oxygen surface group and nitro group leads to an outstanding hydrogenation ability of the corresponding metal catalyst [187]. (iii) Modification of geometric character. The carbon support may also be responsible for the geometry change of the catalytic material. Such type of geometric modification influences the number of active sites in the catalytic reaction [206]. (iv) Stability. The carbon support enhances the stability of the catalytic material. The carbon materials are used also as stabilizer-shell during nitrobenzene hydrogenation and show effective results [210,211]. (v) Avoid metal-catalyst oxidation. The presence of carbon materials with hydrogenation metal-catalysts reduces the metal oxidation ability. The metal-C interaction enhances protect the metal ions from oxidation with higher catalytic stability [210]. In this regard introduction of the heteroatom in carbon reduces undesired by-products as reported by Chen et al. [212]. (vi) Metal support interaction. The metal catalysts and support interaction control the adsorption mechanism and offers a well dispersed catalytic surface [108]. The introduction of heteroatom atom at the carbon support influences such type of interactions more positively for better catalytic efficiency [36]. In this regard, the metal nanoparticle with higher Fermi energy level donate electron to the semiconducting carbon-support and follow Mott-Schottky effect for selective hydrogenation purpose ( Fig. 11). Metal support interaction decides the catalytic performance through activity, selectivity, and recyclability factors. (vii) Easy recovery. The catalytic metal particles are easy recovered from carbon support through easy burning process [121]. In the heterogeneous catalytic support polymorphs carbon materials show high importance. In this regard, graphite, carbon black, activated carbon, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers, polymer derived carbon show much importance in the catalytic selective hydrogenation support according to the previous reported work. 7 The influence of the position of chlorine in the molecule of CNB for selective hydrogenation The importance of chlorine aromatics arises from their huge importance in pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals synthesis. The biologically active chlorine molecule like o-CNB, m-CNB, and p-CNB are chosen for the cost-effective synthesis [213]. In the most stable structure, the geometry of the chloronitrobenzenes follow the energy values as − 896.48, − 896.49, − 896.50 Hartrees respectively for o-, m-, and p-CNB that indicated higher stability of p-CNB. The high stable structure of the para substitution owing to their major resonance and high distance of electronegative chlorine and electron withdrawing nitro group [213]. In a comparative study, the C-C bond distances in ring carbons are varied for o-CNB rather than m- or p-CNB due to the effect of interaction between chlorine and nitro groups. These types of interactions are also responsible for the different ON-O bond distances for ortho-substitution rather than others. In the consideration of C-Cl and C-N bond distances, the value gradually increases for C-Cl and decreases for C-N from o- to m- to p-CNB [213,214]. This type of variation coming from the competition from the mesomeric, inductive effect of the substituent groups and resulting distortion at the point of substitution. Aldo H Brunetti [215] used nuclear quadrupole resonance (NQR) for the identification of ortho- and para- substitution, where no crystalline structure is found for the latter case (sharp NQR signal). The position of chlorine and nitro group in the benzene ring is very significant in terms of their hydrogenation reaction. The selective hydrogenation of CNB leads to the transformation of nitro to aniline without effecting the benzene ring and dechlorination. In the hydrogenation reaction, the rate determining step is depends on the nucleophilic attack of the hydride ion (generate through dissociative adsorption of H2 molecule) and differ according to the derivative of CNB [65,216–218]. As the electron withdrawing -NO2 group influence the hydrogenation reaction, so its position with respect to chlorine is significant in selective hydrogenation in terms of steric or mutual interaction [65]. Beside the electronic properties, π-electron resonance also influences the hydrogenation reaction and differ for different isomers. Campos et al. reported that the hydrogenation reactivity order follows m-CNB > o-CNB > p-CNB and the selectivity is observed as 99%, 100%, and 98% respectively in presence of Au/Fe2O3 catalysts [65]. In presence of Ir/CNT, the isomers follow the same order of the above reactivity with 100% selectivity [136]. According to this study, authors suggested the function of chlorine as electron withdrawing group that activated m-position much more than others (o- and p-CNB) [136]. In case of o-CNB, the presence of -Cl and -NO2 group at the vicinal position leads to the steric hindrance which is not satisfactory for hydrogenation [65]. Again, Ma et al. [219] reported that this trend follows as o- > p- > m- in presence of both Ir/C and Pd/C catalyst. Though this trend of reactivity is also differed as reported for Pt/TiO2 (m- > p- > o-) [136,220], Ni/Ci/CNT (p- > o-) [136,220], 0.85 wt% Pt/C (p- = m- > o-) [14], Au/Al2O3 (o- > p- > m-) [136,221]. Kratky et al. observed the order as p- > o- > m-CNB owing to the support’s electron conductivity that reduced the negative charge of adsorbed hydrogen on metal surface [218]. Again, Mahata et al. also reported there is no dependence of the hydrogenation rate with isomers variation [184]. This type of different activity may be owing to the variation of the supports electron conductivity, metal catalysts oxidation state, different active sites, nitro group adsorption, and generation of adjacent reactions which is related to the rate of the reaction [70,84,218,219]. 8 Parameters that influence the reaction rate 8.1 Reaction temperature The hydrogenation reaction enhanced with the increasing temperature but decreases the product selectivity owing to the acceleration of the dechlorination process [222,223]. The high temperature causes the enhancement of mass transportation and enhance the catalyst activity. The high value of temperature may also lead to the high desorption of the reactants from catalyst surface causes lower selectivity [101]. The selectivity of Pd/C-H catalyst is slightly reduced at high temperature for o-CNB owing to the break of C-Cl bond [224]. Again, Ni/10%TiO2 @OAC (OAC indicates oxygen functionalized activated carbon) showed 100% m-CNB conversion under 2.0 MPa H2 for 4 h at 343 K and the selectivity of aniline increases with rising the temperature from 343 to 363 K [3]. For p-CNB hydrogenation, Ru/RGO catalyst show high efficiency with increasing temperature and 110 oC is noted for 99.6% yield of p-CAN [112]. 8.2 Hydrogen pressure An optimum hydrogen pressure is required for the hydrogenation reaction, high value may also lead to the decreasing the product value [3,101]. The enhancement of pressure causes the adsorption of the reactant on the catalyst surface and forward the reaction in the preferred pathway. As for example, Ni/10%TiO2 @OAC showed high selectivity under 2.0 MPa H2 pressure but decreases at 2.5 MPa [3]. For the Ir/RGO, the catalytic activity slightly enhanced with increasing hydrogen pressure from 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, to 4.0 MPa at 140 oC hydrothermal temperature. This is due to the improved reduction degree of Ir catalyst with increasing pressure proved from XPS study [110]. Ru0.5Pt0.5/Vulcan XC (Vulcan XC indicates types of carbon black) catalyst also exhibited high reaction rate with increasing hydrogen pressure from 1.0 to 7.0 MPa and follow linear relationship [101]. In the hydrogenation of o-CNB over Pd/C–H catalyst, the enhancement of hydrogen pressure from 0.5 MPa to 3 MPa leads to three times higher reaction rate [224]. Increases of H2 pressure from 1 to 3 MPa during liquid phase hydrogenation of Ru/RGO catalyst by Ru/RGO catalyst leads to the enhancement of both the conversion and selectivity. This is due to the higher solubility of hydrogen and presence of active hydrogen at catalyst surface [112]. 8.3 Reaction time Reaction time is another important parameter for the hydrogenation reaction. According to the reaction time the conversion and selectivity performance varies with time owing to the availability of active sites. Fan et al. reported that the hydrogenation of p-CNB becomes 62.9% after 30 min which becomes 100% at 75 min in presence of Ru/RGO catalyst. This larger time taken for total conversion may be owing to the hydrogenation of intermediate product to the desired p-CAN [112]. Kratky et al. showed the stoichiometric hydrogenation of CNB depends on time and varied for different isomers in presence of Pd/C catalyst [218]. 8.4 Other parameters The catalyst activity, selectivity also depends on the particle size [84,98,225], morphology, presence of heteroatom, morphology, surface area [226,227], electronic arrangement [220] etc. The high selectivity for larger particle may be due to the weak adsorption of CAN than CNB on large particle [58,225]. Among the several compounds of nickel sulfide, flowerlike Ni7S6 shows high activity for the selective hydrogenation of CNB owing to their unique surface morphology [226]. Oxidation state of the metal catalyst is one of the important factors. The more electronegative -NO2 group prefer Pd2+ much more than the Pd0 for the selective hydrogenation [98]. Hu et al. [228] investigated the activity of Au/CeO2 catalyst under different solvent where the apparent activation energy follows the order as ethanol>i-butanol>s-butanol>t-butanol>t-pentanol. The hydrogen bond donation ability of the solvent control the above ordered of the reactivity. Presence of water molecule also leads to the promotional effect in the gas-phase hydrogenation reaction [229]. 9 Conclusion and future perspective The review mainly highlights the state-of-art research progress of different carbon form as support materials for selective chloronitrobenzenes hydrogenation. As a low-cost, the support materials are good choice for the easy dispersion of the catalyst through a large surface that enhance the number of active sites. The focus of the review includes the reaction mechanism, selectivity, frequently used catalysts, carbon supports, modification of supports, adsorption, and reaction mode for the selective hydrogenation. The structural prospectus of activated carbon, graphene, CNT, CNF, and their supportive role in the selective hydrogenation reaction is discussed with their supporting mechanistic pathway. In this regard, the role of carbon materials including dispersion effect, modification of electronic character, modification of geometric character, stability, metal-support interaction, and easy recovery of the catalyst show huge impact in the large-scale application. The kinetic study of the hydrogenation process and the mechanism path of the reaction is followed through metal-support interaction, confinement, and spillover phenomenon. These review have yielded some important conclusions such as a) carbon-supported materials' surfaces area are critical for improving metal-support interaction, metal dispersion, and particle size, all of which affect selectivity and conversion of chloronitrobenzenes hydrogenation, b) CNT as catalyst supports show their superior features, such as surface area, strong metal-support connections via π-π stacking interactions, and internal metal anchoring capabilities, as compared to other catalyst supports, c) the presence of second metal atom enhances the activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of CNB, d) the addition of a promoter enhance the catalytic activity through the increase of active surface area, electrical effect, and coordinated unsaturated sites to manage both selectivity and conversion percentage, e) the introduction of heteroatom doped carbon-supported catalyst also boost the selectivity and also reusability. In the future development prospect, the involvement of non-precious metals is more significant for research direction in large-scale application. In this sense, reduction of metal particle corrosion, aggregation, and enhancement of selectivity should be focused. Encapsulating of the metal catalyst inside carbon support is one of the novel strategies (chainmail catalysts) for the enhancement of catalytic lifetime [230]. Electron transportation and redistribution from the metal core to the carbon support leads to the sole catalytic activity [230]. Stable hydrogenation and the sulphur resistant catalyst development is also another important prospect for the value-added chemical production [231]. In this purpose, the regulation of D-band centre of the transition metal should be optimized theoretically and experimentally for high activity [25,231]. The carbon materials as catalyst supports show huge advancement in the catalytic application owing to its versatility in tuning of conductivity, porosity, high surface area, and metal-support interaction factors. The richness of chemistry and physics centered make the carbon materials specialists for various catalytic reactions [189]. In the catalyst support application, a good knowledge should be required about the used carbon materials surface, electronic, mechanical, and morphological characteristics. In this regard, theoretical study may give a new look and prediction about the upcoming work applicability. The applicability of the carbon-support materials in the selective hydrogenation of chloronitroarenes specially chloronitrobenzenes is demanding due to its industrial applicability. Aromatic amine compounds derived from compatible aromatic nitro compounds are key feedstocks for medicines and fine chemicals. However, the existence of a highly reducible substituent creates a difficulty in achieving high chemoselectivity for nitro group reduction. Different activation and treatment processes that can either alter the pore structure or develop surface functional groups can easily manage their pore structure and surface chemistry. Carbon-support in the catalytic reaction have a lot of facilities that already given in the ‘role of carbon support’ section. But the question arise about the limitation and toxicity of these carbon supports towards eco-system after the catalysis process and their fate, transport, biotoxicity. The nanostructured material and their leaching during reaction should be checked after the process. In large-scale application, the blast of such large amount carbon support may create oxidative stress and genotoxicity, and the corresponding facts are serious issues towards the living society. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzenes (CNB) emerges as a prominent topic of interest in catalysis research owing to its enormous industrial importance. However, hydrogenation of CNB is difficult due to the undesired side reaction of hydrodechlorination. As a result, selective nitro group hydrogenation in the presence of other reducing groups (C-Cl) continues to be challenging. Recent research has focused on the development of more selective catalysts. A huge variety of metal-based nanocatalysts and significant research outcomes have been reported in recent years. However, nanoparticle agglomeration and the cost-effectiveness of the catalyst are considered the critical controlling parameter for hydrogenation reactions. Carbon materials have become particularly promising carriers for such hydrogenation processes to overcome this challenge due to their unique chemical and structural properties. More recently, the widespread usage of novel carbons such as carbon nanotubes and graphene, as well as the fine-tuning of surface chemistry with heteroatom doping, have recently opened up new avenues for their applications in catalysis, particularly in CNB hydrogenation. Hence, this review aims at the selective hydrogenation of CNB on carbon-supported metal-based catalysts and summarizes the latest improvements in the use of different carbonaceous materials in this regard, and investigates the role of carbon support through the mechanistic pathway.
coredata.dc:title: A critical review on the role of carbon supports of metal catalysts for selective catalytic hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzenes
